My daughter bought the 'ol Ebay Chinese 40W Laser engraver/cutter. Not bad for the price. Anyway it has no air assist and I didn't want to get the full air compressor, curly hose, etc. So I decided to try a little fan mounting on the head. I tried a few designs with different fan orientations. This one (the third) is the best as the fan doesn't interfere with the range of motion. Early trials are that it's worthwhile. The difference in smoke / flame marks cutting or engraving wood and cardboard is quite dramatic. Haven't tried cutting plastic yet.

The design and implementation is at the "crude" stage. The whole assembly is held on with wire and the openscad file is really bad. I'm starting to work on a solution to get the wire (12v supply) to the head in a sensible and simple fashion. So please take this as an early idea and proof of concept only. There is no fan support bracket yet.

Feel free to improve!!
The design as it stands needs quite a bit of support. Also there is no fan support yet.

comments.text: I see a problem with this design, you are sucking up the exhaust and blowing it across the path of the laser, defeating its purpose. Best to use an external air source like  an air compressor
comments.author: funinthefalls

comments.text: Very true - and a known limitation.  I have since bought a small air compressor and use it. However I did find that this "poor mans" design did help the cut quality quite a lot - especially on materials that tend to burn or char during cutting such as cardboard or wood.
comments.author: funinthefalls

The Babyjogger City Mini is a fantastic baby buggy (love the patented one-handed close mechanism!) but it doesn't come with any hooks or drinks holders. Well here's a simple S-hook for the odd light shopping bag, etc.

They're quick to print so I've put two on a plate - printing two takes only slightly longer than one, once you factor in the warm up and cool down time.

WARNING: HANGING A HEAVY WEIGHT ON THE HANDLES OF A BABY BUGGY CAN CAUSE IT TO TIP BACKWARDS. BE SENSIBLE.

I find this fine at 20% rectilinear infill, but you may want to increase it to make it stronger.

It's probably a good idea for the hook to snap before the weight pulls the buggy over.

We prepared new RepRap 3D printer "clone" - Molestock - based on the concept of printers Rostock and Kossel (Johann C. Rocholl). When designing we were trying to maximally meet the specific needs of the school environment.

The latest version of the parts are available at GitHub (https://github.com/e-Mole/Molestock).

Small example: https://youtu.be/ryqa97hd2Uw
More info: http://www.e-mole.cz/molestock (czech only yet)

Building components list (BOM) in e-Mole 3-4/2015 magazine from page 73 (for download in PDF - http://www.e-mole.cz/cislo/e-mole-c-3-4) (czech only yet).

Building instructions in e-Mole 3-4/2015 magazine (for download in PDF - http://www.e-mole.cz/cislo/e-mole-c-3-4) (czech only yet, but with lots of photos).

comments.text: Great work, congratulations! I'm looking for the igus rail model and i just can't find it in the magazine. Can you inform it to me? Thanks!
comments.author: rsmarcari

comments.text:
Thanks!
We left the IGUS version (accuracy was not very good. It was necessary to double carriage on each tower). Models for IGUS linear guides are still available. If you want to build an IGUS version, use this model Molestock-mag_carriage-v03-IGUS.stl.
We used this IGUS: https://www.igus.com/wpck/3592/drylin_n_NK_02_27 (Now I do not know exactly which variant. If you need to know it exactly, I will find it...)
comments.author: rsmarcari

comments.text: Thanks for de information, if the other solution gives better results, I'll focus on that.
comments.author: ToFe

comments.text: Is there any chance you made a version of the effector that is compatible with E3D V6
comments.author: mattsykes

comments.text:
The E3D V6 radiator diameter is 22 mm. I use radiator of 19 mm diameter (http://obchod.rebelove.org/hotendy-a-trysky/109-chladic-pro-he-rebelmod-v32.html). It would be possible to convert the print-effector for a larger radiator diameter, but I do not have time for that now. But I can provide a RSDOC file (DesignSpark Mechanical or Spaceclaim) for better custom editing.
Another solution is to use a universal plate and make a holder for an E3D radiator. These "extended experimental" parts are on GitHub (https://github.com/e-Mole/Molestock/blob/master/experimental/mag_effector_ext/Molestock-mag_effector_ext-v01.stl).

comments.text:
Stále děláme drobné úpravy, ale nic z toho na GitHubu není (je potřeba všechny změny kriticky projít a vybrat, co má smysl a co ne - není na to bohužel čas). Žádná zásadní změna se nechystá. Směry dalšího vývoje jsou dva - víceextrudérový systém a různé další "ne 3D tiskové" efektory. Bohužel teď na to není moc času :-(
Stavět klidně můžete z dílů na GitHubu. Pokud pro vás má cenu víc extrudérů, tak si dejte nahoru do rámu matičky do všech tří profilů tak, aby se daly dodatečně přidělat ještě dva další držáky na špukly a zavěsit další dva komplety s motory.
comments.author: Kissman

comments.text: Jak moc se zahreji motory na Molestocku? Rad bych tisknul dily na ram z PLA, ale obavam se, ze motory je pri provozu ohreji a ty pak povoli....
comments.author: ToFe

comments.text: Také to tiskneme z PLA - má to pak lepší "tuhost" než v případě ABS. Všechny díly tiskneme s výplní v rozsahu 50-80%. Rohy mají výplň 50 % a zatím se to nikomu nezdeformovalo (motory, které používáme, jsou maximálně "vlažné").
comments.author: Kissman

comments.text: Predpokladam ceske Microcony SX17 a spravne serizene drivery?
comments.author: ToFe

comments.text: Ano, motory od MICROCONU. Při použití driverů krokových motorů bych s Arduinem MEGA asi šel spíše do A4988 než DRV8825. Sice teď používáme DRV8825, ale MEGA je výpočetně slabé a tak se ve výsledku stejně driver defakto degraduje na A4988.

author: PabloCagigal

description.text: Many model railway trees have a very small base with them when purchased. This is my attempt to create a bigger base which means they stand up better and fall over less.
I find print at a low resolution works well (300 micron etc) as the individual extrusions add detail implicitly.

This is my Portable Raspberry Pi game console. It's 3,6 cm thick, 9,6 cm wide and 13,6 cm long. Inside is a Raspberry Pi 2 running Retropie OS which allows it to emulate games from pretty much every single game-system from 1977 to 2003. It has both Raspbian and Kodi installed too.

SCREEN
The screen is a cheap composite backup camera screen from amazon. It has a resolution of 480x320 which might not sound as much, but it's no problem at all when playing retro games. Because the screen is made to work in your car it does need 12V to run out of the box. This however can be fixed easily, so that it runs of 5V :)

BATTERY
Battery wise it has a 6000mAh rechargeable Lithium ion battery which gives it around 4-5 hours of play time.
To charge the battery it has an Adafruit PowerBoost 1000C which can charge the battery in about 5-6 hours.

SOUND
The two built in speakers come from an old broken Nintendo DS Lite I had lying around (those could be replaced by the mini metal speaker from Adafruit). The audio signal coming from the Raspberry Pi is too weak to power the speakers on it's own, so it needs to be amplified. The amplifier is from an old cheap pair of external speakers for an mp3 player that I had lying around too (It could be replaced with a pam8302 amplifier from Adafruit). To turn the volume up and down it has an analog "slider" from an old pair of headphones (You could probably find something similar pretty easily).

BUILT IN CONTROLLER
The built in controller was the hardest part of this project, or more specifically the ANALOG thumb stick. The built in controller I made myself, it's a breadboard PCB with tactile switches, and an analog thumb stick on it. The tact-switches were pretty easy to connect, but I had a lot of trouble with the thumb stick!

ANALOG THUMB STICK
Because it's analog the Raspberry Pi cannot understand it right away. The signal from the thumb stick must be converted to a digital format first. If I had been a master programmer I could probably have gotten away with buying an ADC (analog to digital converter) and then writing a driver for it myself. But that did not work for me :(
So I did some research on the internet, and found that the Arduino could convert analog signals to digital, but since the Arduino was way too big to ever fit in my design I decided to go with an arduino "clone" called the Teensy, because of the much smaller footprint.
After tens of hours of frustration I finally managed to write a working script in a programming language I had never tried before, and get it on to the Teensy! :) (If you have a similar problem you can download the script from the download list "Controller_script_for_Arduino")

DESIGN
Everything except for the components and the four action buttons are designed in Autodesk 123D Design, and 3d printed on an Ultimaker 2. I can definitely recommend both 123D Design and the Ultimaker 2, they've been a solid team all the way through this project.

I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND ANY NON-3D MODELLER TO BUILD THIS PROJECT, SOME OF THE PARTS WILL BE HARD/IMPOSSIBLE TO GET, SO YOU WOULD HAVE TO DO SOME MODIFICATIONS. This is 100% possible since I've included the 123D Design file. But it's on your own risk ;)

SOFTWARE
Retropie is the main operation system, and you select game system and game trhough Emulationstation. Retropie is a great operation system, so go and check it out, if you think it sounds interesting: http://blog.petrockblock.com
Though Retropie is the main operation system, it has both Kodi (XBMC) and Raspbian installed, which means that you can play movies, series and music right on the console! You can even surf the web through Raspbian too, if you have a keyboard connected. Those two operation systems can be launched through Emulationstation as well.

SPECIAL THANKS TO FLOOB from Youtube and Petrockblog/Retropie forum, who helped me through the entire configuration of the built in controller. I could not have made it without his help.

comments.text: What I did to get games to go onto my Pi, was downloading them from emuparadise, using WinRAR extract the game file, put the game file onto a USB thumb drive for later use... Boot up your Pi and login, then type " startx " then press enter and it will bring you to the desktop. Plug that USB drive into your Pi, take the game file and put it onto your desktop for now. Open up the file browser - Open the pi folder - open the RetroPie folder - open the roms folder and find the system that you down loaded the rom for, open that system folder and drag the rom into it. After that Log Out of your Pi, and then in the console type " emulationstation " and it should open up emulationstation: Find your system and game... And Enjoy!!!

Actually I dont use the DSI port... I use the composite jack, which is very easy to solder to.
The internal controller (Teensy) is soldered to the bottom of the 1st usb plug, through a small switch sticking out the side.

I also have another question in regards to the teensy.  Did you connect the mini usb from the teensy to one of one of the four usb pins on the bottom of the raspberry pi?  I was able to program the teensy but was unsure how to wire it.  I wanted to check and see the process you used before proceeding.  Thank you again for assisting me with some of my questions.
comments.author: Rasmushauschild

comments.text:
Yes, the only modification on the screen is the ground wire, which is connected to 12v pin on the regulator.
The Teensy's USB is soldered to the bottom of the first USB plug on the Pi (It must be the first, to make sure it will always register as player 1) To avoid making that USB port unusable for other things it made a little switch on the right side of the console, which cuts the ground connection for the Teensy, making the USB port free again.
Hope this answers your questions :)

title: Fan duct and Mini Differential IR sensor v1.1 mount for E3Dv6 hot end on Kossel

description.text:
This is for mounting a 40mm hot and cooling fan and Mini Differential IR height sensor board version 1.1 (see https://miscsolutions.wordpress.com/mini-height-sensor-board/) on a Kossel with E3Dv6 hot end.

Updated 2015-08-17 to raise the sensor board by 0.5mm and add alternative effector mounting hole centres. The STL file suffixed -mk is for the Mini Kossel effector, the one suffixed -rd is for the Robotdigg aluminium effector.

Updated 2016-06-25 to enable Customizer and to provide an option for the larger E3D heater block that accommodates a PT100 or thermocouple temperature sensor.

This design places the version 1.1 sensor board below the heatsink of the E3Dv6 hot end, allowing the sensor to be placed closer to the nozzle. When printed without support, the bridge may be a little messy, but you can clean up the worst of it with a file and the rest will be hidden by the cooling fan. To assemble, first check that the print will fit easily over the groove of the E3Dv6 and file the print if necessary. Mount a straight 3-pin PCB header on the component side of the sensor board. Trim the pins and component wires on the back of the board. Attach the sensor as shown using two M2.5 countersunk screws, then cover the back of the board with 2 layers of Kapton tape. Fit the printed part over the groove of the E3D with the narrow part of the heater block facing the back of the board and parallel to it - DO NOT grip and twist the heater block to align it or you may damage the heat break. Fit a 40mm x 10mm cooling fan on the front.

author: dc42

title: Kinect Neck Support
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: So here's my first thing. Its pretty utilitarian. I bought an XBox 360 Kinect for 3D scanning and it turns out there's a fair amount of play in the neck joint. I plan to mount the Kinect on a pistol grip for hand held scanning so I would like it to be more rigid. I made this small ring which snaps around the support arm, bracing the bottom of the sensor against the top of the base, essentially fixing things in place. Its easily removable if you need to use the built in motor at a later date.

This was modelled in Vectorworks 2013. I prototyped it using Makerware and a Makerbot Replicator 2.  
I printed the final version in black PLA with a layer height of 0.20mm, an infill of 10% and one shell. I used a Makerware custom profile adjusted for my actual filament diameter.  
The ring slides onto the Kinect neck from the side. The top of the ring is flat while the bottom is hollowed out to fit around the ball joint at the base of the neck (the STL is upside down for printing).

title: Parametric JHead / E3D holder with ring Led and Inductive Sensor Support

description.text:
I need to replace my default FolgerExtruder in order to enlight my X carriage.
So I choose use a JHead and a bowden extruder (provided in an other post).
I made my version just to be able to add inductive sensor and ring light.
It's a parametric version so it could fit to any other Mendel/JHead/Fan/Sensor/...
I prefer to print individual parts in order to limit printing issue and be able to fix and print a little part instead of a big one.

Work's still in progress I didn't printed it yet...

author: Dokart

description.text:
This is an organizer for some of the medication and the injection supplies for an IVF cycle. It is designed to keep the daily hassle of injections to a minimum. This organizer keeps all injection supplies and just a few doses of medication on hand, while the remaining boxes and vials are stored in the fridge or out of the way until you need to open them.

Compartments:

  • Documents: For your drug facts, protocol info, schedule, or any paperwork you want right there.
  • Pen injector: One Gonal F or Follistim pen. I ended up keeping a normal pen for writing in this compartment as well.
  • Syringes: Regular ol' syringes. This compartment fit about 15 3ml syringes. If you're on a long Lupron protocol, stock it with the syringes from that box first and then mix in some 3ml ones as you begin stimming.
  • Q-Caps: For easy mixing. You get 5 in each box of Menopur or Bravelle, and fertility clinics hand them out like candy. This slot can fit 6 at once.
  • Needles: The fat ugly needles that come on your 3ml syringes are NOT the ones you inject with, although they are easier to mix with if you don't have Q-Caps. This slot is for the 27 or 30Ga needles that you'll do SQ injections with, or the 22 or 25Ga needles for IM injections.
  • Prep pads: Lots of room here for alcohol swabs, and for gauze squares in case you start bleeding.
  • Medicine vials: Two compartments, each large enough for 4 small vials (Menopur, Sodium Chloride solution, Bravelle, etc) or 1 large vial (Lupron, PIO).
  • Pen needles: A slot for all the little needle caps for Gonal F or Follistim pens.
  • Syringe Rest: In case you need to put down the syringe, or you want to put the Gonal F cap down somewhere where it won't roll away.

On storage of medication: Every IVF protocol is different, and this storage is only suitable for medications that are stable at room temperature. Some medications that are stable at room temp may last longer in the fridge (e.g. Gonal-F, Menopur), so this is designed to keep only your next few doses at room temp. Some medications shouldn't be refrigerated at all (e.g. Lupron, PIO), and others should always be refrigerated (e.g. Cetrotide).

Additionally, some medications should be protected from light (e.g. Lupron, Del Estrogen). For these, keep them in the little carton, instead of leaving the vial out where it is exposed to light.

Double check on your drug facts sheets and call your nurse or pharmacist if you're not sure about any of this!

NOTE: The STL file is for the light blue print. The dark blue one is a first draft. The light blue one is slightly larger and can store 4 small vials in each medicine slot instead of the 2 each pictured. In addition, the updated design has thinner walls and fewer bottom layers for significantly faster print times. The 123D Design file is also attached if you need to customize the design.

PRINTING INSTRUCTIONS: You will need a 150mm x 150mm bed size to print this organizer. I printed at .3mm. Set your print speed to the fast side of normal; the long straight lines of the design mean that resonance issues will be minimized. I printed at 60mm/sec on a Printrbot Metal Simple, but would probably increase those speeds to 80mm/sec if I were to print it again.
When the dinosaurs return, they'll need something to destroy... what's better than the eifel tower?

These are 2 simple propeller designs that do print ok.   
Print them at 'normal' or 'fine' rates, use support.  
Print with the cone pointing upwards.  
Print with as many surface layers as your printer supports, then drill out the hole to match the shaft diameter of your motor.   
The photo shows a simple hovercraft we made using the 'broad blade' version of the 2 propellers, a simple 'Y' frame we printed to suit the motor and a disposable plastic dinner plate. It was just to test the fans (the broad blade seems most efficient).

This is a tennis ball holder that can be screwed on any bicycle that has drill holes for a bottle holder.

Tired of not knowing how to transport a tennis ball with the bike?
Here's the final solution.
Does't matter if you simply want to have a ball handy when going out with the dog (like me) or if you play bike-tennis or are a professional tennis ball forwarding company.

The tennis ball holder can also be mounted on cars, hovercrafts and tanks - if you don't have a bicycle.

title: Y-wing Stack-able Stanley Tool Box Bins

description.text: The picture does not show the 3rd peg and that was added after printing. This was designed to fit 3 Y-Wings stacked on top of each other in the Stanley tool box. The bot/mid file will work for the lower two layers and a top file is included without the top pegs. The dimensions were broadened a bit after seeing someone try and print Byrden's original model and have fitting issues.
0.2 resolution, 10% Infill, PLA, 60/120 mm/s. Power Spec 3D.

comments.text: These fit fine in the Harbor Freight small and medium cases.  When stacked they don't quite reach the lid, there's maybe a quarter inch gap.  However, length and width wise they fit perfectly.

author: royeiror

description.text:
There's a great big beautiful tomorrow
Just a dream away
-- The Sherman Brothers 1964

I've been kicking around this unfinished model for almost a year now, and after a recent trip to the Walt Disney Family Museum in San Francisco I decided I had finish it off.

The museum has a great exhibit on the 1964 World's Fair and the Carousel Of Progress ride (which has been recreated at Walt Disney World's Magic Kingdom). This model is a replica of the sign outside of the ride at the Magic Kingdom. It's always been a favorite of mine so I decided to print and paint a tiny copy for my desk.

I've included the STLfor printing and the SketchUp SKP if you'd like to make modifications

I printed this model without supports and at 10% infill.

The sections were painted with:

  • Citadel Fire Dragon Bright
  • Citadel Teclis Blue
  • Citadel Ceramite White
  • Model Color Violet

Then all the parts were glued together using super glue

I learned how to 3-D print this week, and created a little rocket nightlight. It's hollow, so you put a little LED light inside and it lights up!
This rocket is hollow, but it is closed, so you'll have to drill a hole at the bottom to place a light inside.

Friend wanted a tie clip with his name on it, so he could use it instead of those crappy paper name tags.  Decided there was a need for a fully customizable tie clip on thingiverse, so here it is.  
Enjoy.

A couple of notes, the Black Rose font tends to default a bit low, adding 0.5mm of offset is recommended.  Also, of the different fonts, the default and the Orbitron are the most readable when printed.  Black Rose looks great with some cleanup and then painted with a sharpie or other paint to increase contrast.

comments.text: Any other suggestions on printing this? Layer height?
comments.author: jrombousky

comments.text: Layer height is dependant on size and quality you desire.  I normally print at 0.15mm and the text turns out quite nice.  I think I tried one at 0.05mm once and it actually turned out worse due to the overhangs from the text which turned out worse at the lower layer heights (the lift off on that particular print may have also been part of the problem, so take with a grain of salt).  Never tried at any other layer heights, so can't really advise optimum settings.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bBjkyJ003Cz

This is a model of part of a helicoid with parametric equations x(t)=u.cos(t), y(t)=u.sin(t), and z(t) = 2t/3, where the parameter u goes between -1 and 1. The parameter t goes between 0 and Pi for the half-twist, goes between 0 and 2Pi for the full-twist.

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Emily Jaekle ('16). See http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2015/07/27/helicoids/.

We printed these helicoids on a FormLabs Form 1+ liquid resin printer. The half-twist helicoid was printed in black resin (0.1mm slices), the full-twist helicoid in clear resin (0.2mm slices). The print was excellent in both cases. (The .form files we used are included.)

Note: we had tried to print the half-twist on the MakerBot 2X, but had two fails. It might well print if additional supports are added - however we haven't figured this out.

This is a (3,2) torus knot with the label T(3,2) added to the knot. One file has the knot with the label, the other with no label.

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Ryan McDonnell('17). See http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2015/07/27/torus-knots/.

This object was printed on a FormLabs Form 1+ printer using the grey resin. We used 0.1mm slices and the print took 23.5mL. (The .form file used to print the object is included. )

The print came out really well :-)

remixed_from.author: sillano
remixed_from.title: Parametric fast-clamp OpenSCAD library for K8200/3Drag

title: Fast-clamp mounting for original K8200/3Drag extruder

description.text:
A fast and simple extruder mounting system is really useful to replace it in accident case, or to use different extruders for different materials, or to use a drill or ...

We need 2 things;
1) A robust clamping system
2) A plug for the electrical connections

Here you can find this 2 things:
1) a good support for the original K8200/3Drag extruder. I made it using the library fast-clamp http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:936871.
2) a box to fix the male plug (I choose a DB9 connector) at the extruder structure.

Thanks to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:203292 for the extruder horizontal support plate, added here for convenience.

No visible difference in printed things using the original or this clamped support.

Complete collection of Add-on for 3Drag/K8200 using Fast Clamp: http://www.thingiverse.com/sillano/collections/3drag-fast-clamp-addon

• print all 3 + 2 parts
    (tested using PLA, layer 0.2, perimeter 6 layers, infill 80%-100%)
  • use the M4 threaded rod and 2 self-locking nuts to tie the noose and link parts.
    Attention to parts position.
  • use 2 screws M4 flat head, to fix the original support plate on the clamp.
  • solder 8 wires from the extruder (4x Nema, 2x head, 2x thermistore) to the DB9 male plug, and the flat cable to female plug. ( record the cable/pin association)
  • fix plug to cubic case using 2 M3 screws
  • mount the DB9 case in the back of the extruder using a long M4 screw
  • mount the female plug case.

Extra:

  • DB9 male solder D-sub connector.
  • DB9 female solder D-sub connector with case.
  • threaded rod M4 80 mm long, 2 washers and 2 self-locking nut (for click)
  • screws: 2 x M4 flat head, 35 mm long and M4 lock washer, M4 nut (for clip)
  • screw: 2 x M3 and M3 washer, M3 nut for the DB9 plug.
  • screw: 1 x M4 long 60 and M4 washer, M4 lock washer, M4 nut for the case plug.

comments.text: Looks like an excellent combination of parts.  Have just constructed the standard K8200 model but will consider this modular improvement soon.  Thanks for sharing your design.
comments.author: HLH

title: Fast-clamp replacing original fan mount for k8200/3drag

description.text:
This frame mounting can be used to replace the original fan support.
Easy fan positionning or removing is the major advantage of this thing.
As an example, i prefere the fan to be placed at the back of the extruder, where it cooperates to keep cold also the support clamp.
This thing uses modules defined in the library fast-clamp http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:936871, so it is
easy to design and to use. You don't need any tool to place and remove the fan.

Complete collection of Add-on for 3Drag/K8200 using Fast Clamp: http://www.thingiverse.com/sillano/collections/3drag-fast-clamp-addon

Instructions (stl file):

  • print all 3 parts
    (tested using PLA, layer 0.2, perimeter 6 layers, infill 80%-100%)
  • use a M4 screw and self-locking nut to tie the noose and link parts.
    Attention to parts position.
  • use the original M4 screw to fix in place the fan.

Modifications (scad file):
To use the fan-clamp.scad file, you also need the library fast-clamp05.scad, added here for your convenience.

extra:
screws: 1 x M4, 25 mm long and self-locking M4 nut (for clip)

description.text:
This frame mounting is for a simple led light using USB.
This thing uses modules defined in the library fast-clamp http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:936871 so it is
easy to design and use. You don't need any tool to place and remove the light.

Complete collection of Add-on for 3Drag/K8200 using Fast Clamp: http://www.thingiverse.com/sillano/collections/3drag-fast-clamp-addon

extra:
led light using USB (made in China)
screws: 1 x M4 50 mm long and self-locking M4 nut (for clip)
4 x Parker (self tapping) 5 mm (for the cover).

Instructions (stl file)

  • print all 4 parts
    (tested using PLA, layer 0.2, perimeter 6 layers, infill 80%-100%)
  • use a M4 screw and self-locking nut to tie the noose and link parts.
    Attention to parts position.
  • use 4 screws to block cover and UBS plug.

Modifications (scad file)
To use the led-clamp.scad file, you also need the library fast-clamp05.scad, added here for your convenience.

author: emiliheli

description.text:
Have you ever wanted to harness the power of the wind?, No? Well you will now with these racers. Simply make a hole using tinkercad and put in a pinwheel and watch it go.
What makes it even better is that it is completely open for customization, you can make it anything you want. Want to throw a flux capacitor in there? go right ahead if you are brave enough. You can even go crazy and add two pinwheels to it.
Warning!: Adding two pinwheels can cause the racer to warp into hyper drive. Attempt this at your own risk, I am not a responsible for any dimensional travel.

UPDATE: Holy Flying Tuna Fish Batman!!!!!, the Bat Mobile has entered the pinwheel race.
Update 2: I have adjusted the scaling on the files and have elongated the body as well as increased the size and rounded out the wheels. The axles also were made longer and shaped better. The new files are under the updated zip. The top shell covers now all have to be re-scaled to match the bottom base.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=93u7taaW8h4
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2IHvJWiUzR4
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qfawDkBtnOs

Simply insert axle in and glue the tires to it. Make a hole on the top base before printing using tinkercad or your preferred software. Then you can connect the top and bottom base however you may like, whether its glue or tape. Lastly, simply insert any store bought pinwheel and let it get some wind.
Customize the top base however you want and make it yours. Make it a tank, plane, or even a T-rex (awesome), the possibilities are endless.
Future Update will contain a bat mobile kit.

comments.text: I was just able to get my hands on a 3D print of my design thanks to a coworker. I noticed that adjustments need to be made to the wheels and axle to shape them better. Also the body needs to grt elongated. I will upload the updated files in the morning. Thank you for all the support.

Horde or Alliance, battle on with this weapon!

title: Modified Vertical Axis Wind Turbine (1/4" Motor Shaft)

description.text: Intro

I have a motor that I wanted to test with Hooptey's Vertical Axis Wind Turbine. He was kind enough to post the SLDPART's so I went to work and modified both the hub and the arms. The changes are:
  • Attachment screws changed to 3.12mm locking Torx screws (http://www.mcmaster.com/#99397A626) on both arms and hub
  • Hub gear removed and modified to have 1/2" shaft instead. Shaft locked in by 1/4"-20 x 1/4" coarse thumbscrew.
  • Rain protection built into hub, and optional rain cover
  • Motor mount added
    • Testing

Testing began with the finishing of version 6. It was a massive failure. Not only was wind not very strong, but I did not have blades required (the blinds). Instead I cut out cardboard blades.   
When tested with a leaf blower it became clear that there is a specific angle that must be caught. The arms will have to be changed.   
Another issue could be I need gearing to turn the motor, but there is so little force needed it might not be needed.   
After a little research, it would make sense to do longer blinds, and possibly more arms.
Parts List

• 3.12mm locking Torx screws (http://www.mcmaster.com/#99397A626) NOTE: These are what I have on hand, and this might change!
  • Motor:
    • 2â€ body diameter x 3-3/4â€ long
    • 1/4â€ shaft diameter
    • 140 volt 3700 RPM
  • Four (4) x 1/4"-20 x 1/4" coarse thumbscrew
Change List

• v7
    • Rain cover eliminated
    • Second tier added, held together by 1/2" garden poll / screw
    • Rear Motor Mount changed slightly
    • Hub Top added. Used for second tier.
    • Main Hub Extender added.
  • v6: Mount added to Rear Motor Mount
  • v5:
    • Rain cover added
    • Hole diameter for motor mounts modified
    • Mount polls made circular, one screw eliminated
    • Rear Motor Mount wire hole added
  • v4:
    • Motor mounts added
    • Minor mods to thumbscrew hole diameter
  • v3 (optional): Hub rain cover added
  • v2:
    • Hub strengthened in middle
    • Thumb screw changed to 1/4"-20x1/4"
    • Arm and hub attachement holes resized for 3.12mm screws (now wider!)
    • Shaft widened a bit to counter ABS shrinkage
    • Infill recommendation changed to 50%
  • v1: Initial release, unprinted
Printing

50% infil, 1 shell
  • 1 x Main Hub
  • 1 x Top Hub
  • 2 x Hub Extender
  • 6 x Arms
  • 1 x Front Motor Mount
  • 1 x Rear Motor Mount
    • 100% infill, 1 shell
  • 2 x Mount Polls
    • Assembly

Each arm can be attached to the hub by 3 x 3.12mm Torx self threading screws. Make sure to first place the hub extenders in line with the outer two arm screws on each arm. The hub extenders allow you to add layers. You can add as many layers are you want! Alternately, the holes can be widened slightly and standard M3 hardware (10mm screw, M3 bolt) may be used.  
Motor should be enclosed in the motor mount pieces. Place the front motor mount in place and attach with included motor machine screws. Next attach the polls to the Front Motor Mount. 1 x 3.12mm Torx self threading screw needs to be used. Finally attach the Rear Motor Mount and attach in the same way you did the front. The same type of thumbscrew used to attach the shaft to the hub can be used to attach a gardening pole (1/2") to the Rear Motor Mount.

title: GoPro Barrel Mount For Paintball guns!

description.text:
Version 1 is a GoPro Barrel Mount for a tipmann A5 though it will probably work on the 98 and X7 as well. Leave a comment if you need a different barrel size, just leave the diameter of the barrel and I can make it!

Update Mount V2:
So after getting one request for a different size I went ahead and looked at my other barrels and noticed they can be all sorts of different so I made Version 2, new and improved. The diameter is slightly larger and is much easier to put on any barrel since it is in two pieces. If it isn't working for some of your barrels let me know the issue and I will work on it.

This is printed with ABS at a 232 tip and 100 heat bed. I did a solid filling though that makes it less flexible to slip on the barrel so maybe 80% would be better. It is a super snug fit so it is some work to get on the barrel, pretty much have to screw it on the thread side of the barrel.

The screw holes for tightening the mount to the barrel are 6mm in diameter.

title: End Cap for 3/4" Electrical Conduit Pipe on Mostly Printed CNC

description.text:
Update 4/9/2016
Rev12: Added option to cut corner off outside to clear Belt Tensioning part. The 1st photo shows what this looks like.

While waiting on some parts, I decided to design & print some conduit caps. This fits the Standard 3/4" electrical Pipe. I included the openscad source if you need to tweak the diameter a little or make it to fit the metric pipe. I could not find the specs on Internal Diameter of the metric 25mm OD pipe.

Looks like it should clear the belts & the hole is sized for the cable that comes with Allted's standard kit. You can leave the hole out for corner pipes, but I am leaving mine in just in case I need to take those caps out at some point down the road. You can use 3mm allen wrench to pull it back out if you print it with this size hole. It might be more difficult to take them out without that hole access. Also when installing this, if the wire is coming from the other end, it might be easier to put the wire coming from the pipe thru the end cap before inserting the cap.

I used 21mm as the diameter for my 3/4" pipe which snaps right in. I printed about 4 or 5 different sizes before settling on this Diameter & profile.

I could make this work in the customizer, but if you adjust the diameter, it is kind of a trial and error to get the height of the smushed sphere in the right spot. I might could make that a rotated extrusion instead of a smushed sphere, if someone needs more flexibility there.

title: MakerGear M2 rear cable harness guide

description.text: I used to have the cable harness on my M2 cable-tied to the outside of the printer's frame on the right side. However, when I installed the dual extruder upgrade, I quickly discovered that the wire harness interfered with the filament spools, which were also on the right side. So I moved the wire harness to the inside of the frame. There, though, it has barely enough room and brushes up against the heated bed bracket. So I designed a channel for the cable harness that puts the cables behind and in line with the frame, where they are not in the way of either the Z-stage assembly or filament spools on the right side. And it keeps things neat and tidy.

This part needs to print vertically, as that is the only orientation that does not put filament layer separation lines in the same direction as stress points, especially when the guide is pried open to stuff the cable harness in. Because the height is greater than the maximum Z height of the M2 (by definition, really), it has been split into two parts which overlap over the middle hole in the frame.

First remove any cable ties from the harness along the left side of the frame, then carefully pry open the guide and slip the harnesses into position. Then slide the assembly onto the frame. Bolt onto the frame using three (preferably) M4 x 12 machine screws with washers (M3 will also do, and I had some M3 x 12 screws left over from the printer kit supplies)

This is the curve parametrized by x=cos(t), y=sin(t), z=1/(1+t^2) from t=-2pi to t=2pi. One .stl file has the equations on the curve, the second does not.

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Ryan McDonnell ('17).

We printed this curve on a FormLabs Form 1+ liquid resin printer. It was printed in black resin (0.1mm slices), The print was excellent in both cases. (The .form file we used is included.)

We think this curve could also be successfully printed on a MakerBot, (or other plastic filament printer) but have not tried this yet.
You might need to make the holes a bit bigger, depending on your printer and/or configuration. The dimensions are the same as on the original.

description.text:
This is a (2,3) torus knot with a variety of options for printing.

The 2_3_torus_knot_new.stl is a larger, thinner model (shown in grey). One option has the label T(2,3) on the knot, the other option does not have a label.

The 2_3_torus_knot_subscript.stl is a smaller, fatter model (shown in black). One option has the label T with the subscripts 2,3, the other option does not have the label. (The label is a little small in this model.)

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Ryan McDonnell('17). See http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2015/07/27/torus-knots/.

This object was printed on a FormLabs Form 1+ printer using the both the black and grey resin for the smaller and larger prints respectively. We used 0.1mm slices for both prints. The .form files used to print the objects are included.

The print came out really well in both cases :-)

We haven't tried printing this on the MakerBot printer yet.

This is a plane that I have been designing in Autocad after the RQ 11 plane for our robotics program at Idaho State University. I have been working on printing it so we can fly it this summer. For more infomation on the projects that we work on please visit: https://sites.google.com/a/isu.edu/rcet-projects/ or the club site at http://www.isurobotics.com/ STL files to come soon after I print and check everything.

title: Toilet Roll Holder for work dunny cubicles

description.text:
Does your work have these annoying stacking roll holder/dispensers that are a mongrel to get the paper out?
Mine does! Hence this quick addition.
It should fit most of the common Bowscot type roll stackers - flat or angled lid.

This sits best on the stacker when clipped on facing forward.
  • Print.
  • open lid of dunny roll stacker.
  • IF lid = locked THEN pick lock. ENDIF.
  • place roll holder on and reload!
  • Say goodbye to frustration!
    • Prints best with finger facing upwards. Support will be needed for the lower section. Printed in white PLA on an UP! printer.
    0.15mm layers, fine quality (very slowly for best layer bond).

This is the curve parametrized by x=tcos(t), y=tsin(t), z=t from t=0 to t=5pi. There are several versions of the curve:
1) spiral_new_merged.stl file has the equations imprinted on the curve - we think this is the best file to print.
2) spiral_thick.stl has equations on the curve, but jutting out of the curve.
3) spiral_thick_no_equations.stl is just the curve used in each print.

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Ryan McDonnell ('17).

We first printed this (spiral_thick.stl) on a MakerBot 2X printer. The curve was rotated so the axis of rotation was upright. The print was OK, but the top part of the spiral melted a bit, there was not quite enough support there. The equations were not particularly strongly attached.

We redesigned the equations (spiral_new_merged.stl) and printed it on the FormLabs Form 1+ printer. The .form file is included. It worked beautifully. Though we expect this print to work well on the MakerBot too.

title: Filament sponge for Prusa i3 Hephestos

description.text:
There is always a bit of dust on your filament spool and I had problems with thunderbugs which invaded into my monitor and my filament spool.
I wanted to prevent them from entering my extruder and influence the print result or block the heater.
So I decided to print a small case for a sponge. It doesn't need any support and prints at a layer height of 0.3mm within 20 minutes.

On Prusa i3 Hephestos it stands fine on the extruder. Might fit on many other printers as there is no special mounting required.

Feel free to modify this design. I attached the OpenSCAD design file as well as a rendered STL.

Doesn't need to be precise, so you can print in a layer height of 0.3mm. After printing, cut 15mm x 15mm blocks out of a sponge. I used a sponge with a height of 8mm, so I put two layers of this into the box. Make a hole into both sponges and put the filament through.

title: Helium Filament From Destiny The Game

description.text: This is my model of the upgrade item Helium Filaments from the game destiny. Use these files to make your very own Helium Filament from Destiny so you can complete your cosplay or just store it in your vault. I modeled this in 123D design then exported as a STL file for 3Dprinting.

You need to print the top and bottom once and the ring and side rail four times.The Bottom and top parts both need support and could use raft if you want. The side bar and ring parts don't need support but you could use raft if you would like. use Acetone to glue the pieces together then paint with the colors you want. I designed this to use a 1 1/2 inch clear PVC pipe. Then use yellow EL wire and a small lipo battery to light up the inside.

author: Dylandude101

description.text:
This is a very useful Vice style, self centering Clamp that is 3D printable on most RepRap printers out there. Recommended materials are Nylon or Carbon Fiber filament for stiffness and durability. Use M6 screws and nuts to mount it together and find some 3mm Diameter sticks to fit the ''hands'' to the ''arms'' (see names of components ''Main'' and ''Bras'' in the model for reference).
For our particular needs (PhotoVoltaic cell characterisation apparatus), I made those 8mm diameter, 3.1mm deep holes for some standard super magnets that will be super glued in place to hold a 0.7 thick steel sheet, custom cut, to be able to place micromanipulators on top of it with more super magnets. The 2x M6 screws and nuts half-holes between the 2 big parts (Body Top and Bottom) are 75mm apart to match labware metric standard, but in our case this is the attachment method to mount this clamp to the Gimbal of the apparatus once the PV sample has been clamped and micromanipulators adjusted under a microscope.
As I show in this model, the ''arms'' of the calmp can be taken out and inverted to be able to clamp smaller objects.
I included the SketchUp model so you can modify and adapt it to your specific needs. Note this clamp is not heavy duty as is, you migh want to design new arms for that...
Enjoy! :)

circular plate has diameter of 33mm
hole has a diameter of 6mm
Screw hole accepts a 3,5mm countersunk screw or bolt.

Print preferrably in ABS (for strength)
I increased the wall thickness and bottom/top thickness to 1.2mm for additional strength.
A few of the nocks kept falling out of my arrows. Friend gave me the idea to print replacements. This is the result.

Due to small size, probably best to print with small layer height, slow speed, 100% infill, heated bed and/or brim.

I've only test printed 1 so far (pictured), with .1mm layer height, 30mm/s speed and on heated bed (no brim). It warped a bit, slower speed/brim might have helped.

title: LulzBot Mini Build Plate for use with Simplify3D

description.text: I like the ability that Simplify3D allows a model of the printer to be added as a reference when laying out a print bed. I use a LulzBot Mini and Simplify3D doesn't come with a model for the Mini by default so I made my own! I assembled the model from STL's and drawings retrieved from http://devel.lulzbot.com/

Place the STL into the ..AppData->Local->Simplify3D->S3D-Software folder (in Windows). Then, with S3D open and your LulzBot Mini process selected go to Tools->Options (on Windows) and then select the 'Machine' tab. In the 'Printer Models' section, click on the 'Add' button and browse for the STL that you just placed. Once you press OK, the model should appear!

title: Simple Spool holder for 65mm Filament spool

description.text:
This spool holder is made to work with 608z bearings, so print the file, it has pins that just push in to the holes to hold the bearings in place, it might need a dab of glue on the points of the pins to stop them from sliding out. But this design works perfectly.

Let me know what you think about it in the comments.

comments.text: Thanks for sharing! I like how you included the hardware as a 3D printed part. It makes assembly a but more convenient. I may make a variant for my spool of choice as I've been looking to design something similar to this for a while now.

comments.text: Its a pleasure, I'm glad you like it. Keep me posted on how your holder looks when you are done. =D
